pages.title: InfoV.A.C.
pages.content:
InfoV.A.C.®

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

Negative Pressure Wound Therapy System

The InfoV.A.C.® Therapy System is an in-patient KCI Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT) system that uses SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology (Therapeutic Regulated Accurate Care) to assure the prescribed negative pressure setting is delivered to the wound site. The InfoV.A.C.® Therapy System is:

  • Specifically designed for the acute care patient with exudating wounds requiring 500mL or 1000mL canisters.
  • Designed with the clinician in mind to make V.A.C.® Therapy easy to use providing enhanced features such as Seal Check™, Therapy History Reports and Digital Wound Imaging.
  • This software-controlled advanced wound care technology can be used on a variety of chronic and acute wounds.
  • It can be readily integrated into the clinician’s wound healing practice, helping to optimize patient care.

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
For the acute care setting, features of the therapy unit include

  • Lightweight (5.9 pounds)
  • Compact size
  • A full-color user interface with intuitive touch screen controls for simplified navigation
  • Alarm notifications that are easy to recognize and correct
  • Easy, quick release 500 and 1000mL canister options
  • 6-hour battery
  • SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology monitors and maintains target pressure
  • Digital wound image feature allows healthcare professionals to measure and calculate wound area and volume, which helps wound progress assessment
  • IV pole and bedside positioning capabilities and easy, single-hand canister removal
  • Includes a USB port, memory card slot, or infrared for convenient data download

Seal Check™ Feature

Designed to help clinicians and patients identify and troubleshoot negative pressure leaks, Seal Check™ provides:

  • Instant Feedback. Audio and visual cues are delivered in real-time, allowing easy location of dressing leaks.
  • Enhanced Therapy Confidence. A proper seal helps provide accurate delivery of prescribed therapy for wound healing.

Settings Guide

Recommended therapy settings and pressure ranges are pre-programmed into the unit based on the indicated wound types, allowing for:

  • Easy Set Up. With pre-programmed settings by wound type, clinicians can initiate therapy quickly and efficiently.
  • Simple Usage. Intuitive control functions make it easier to use, especially for clinicians who are not as familiar with V.A.C.® Therapy.

Therapy History Reports

With its built-in ability to store and track therapy data, healthcare professionals can:

  • Document patient compliance with V.A.C.® Therapy. Monitors therapy usage, settings, durations, and dressing and canister changes to help ensure patients are receiving the prescribed course of therapy.
  • Stay Informed. Information can be downloaded to a USB flash drive, SD memory card, or transmitted via Infrared to a PDA for further analysis.

Digital Wound Imaging

Clinicians can upload and store wound images to the InfoV.A.C.® Therapy System. This feature can help:

  • Document Wound Progression. Physicians can view wound images any time, allowing flexibility in viewing the wound.
  • Enable Analysis. Helps calculate wound area and volume.

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The InfoV.A.C.® Negative Pressure Wound Therapy Systems are integrated wound management systems for use in acute, extended and home care settings.

When used on open wounds, they are intended to create an environment that promotes wound healing by secondary or tertiary (delayed primary) intention by preparing the wound bed for closure, reducing edema, promoting granulation tissue formation and perfusion, and by removing exudate and infectious material. Open wound types include: chronic, acute, traumatic, subacute and dehisced wounds, partial-thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure or venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

When used on closed surgical incisions, they are also intended to manage the environment of surgical incisions that continue to drain following sutured or stapled closure by maintaining a closed environment and removing exudates via the application of negative pressure wound therapy.

pages.title: V.A.C.Via
pages.content:
V.A.C.Via™

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product information for use prior to application.

Negative Pressure Therapy System

Device Disposal: At the end of therapy, follow local institutional protocols for infection control and waste disposal procedures for dressings and canisters. Local protocols for the disposal of the V.A.C.Via™ device should be based on applicable federal, state and/or local government environmental regulations for recycling electronic devices.

The V.A.C.Via™ Negative Pressure Wound Therapy System stands on the solid foundation of proven V.A.C.® Therapy.

  • First for-sale NPWT system and is portable, lightweight and disposable.
  • Designed for single patient use providing 7 days of V.A.C.® Therapy.
  • Simple to use, it allows the user to select negative pressure settings of either 75 or 125mmHg and either continuous or Dynamic Pressure Control mode of Negative Pressure Wound Therapy.

Use V.A.C.Via™ Therapy Unit for wounds presenting with:

  • Less than or equal to 250cm3 in size
  • Low to moderate levels of exudate with volumes of 80cc or less per day

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
Easy for patients

  • Silent
  • Small, sleek design
  • Lightweight

Easy for clinicians

  • Simple operation
  • Minimal training required
  • Single-patient use
  • Streamlined access

Customized therapy options

  • Continuous negative pressure (75mmHg or 125mmHg)
  • Dynamic Pressure Control Therapy (Evolution of intermittent therapy that maintains minimum pressure levels (25mmHg) in the wound bed between therapy cycles)
  • Delivers 7 days of NPWT

V.A.C.Via™ Therapy Unit offers

  • Simplified access: Easy availability for immediate wound therapy.
  • Streamlined patient care: Enhanced mobility and convenience, so patients can receive 7 days of V.A.C.® Therapy anywhere, allowing for the potential of faster transition from the hospital.
  • Single-use design: The first disposable V.A.C.® Therapy device, for added flexibility.

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The V.A.C.Via™ Negative Pressure Wound Therapy Systems are integrated wound management systems for use in acute, extended and home care settings.

When used on open wounds, they are intended to create an environment that promotes wound healing by secondary or tertiary (delayed primary) intention by preparing the wound bed for closure, reducing edema, promoting granulation tissue formation and perfusion, and by removing exudate and infectious material. Open wound types include: chronic, acute, traumatic, subacute and dehisced wounds, partial-thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure or venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

When used on closed surgical incisions, they are also intended to manage the environment of surgical incisions that continue to drain following sutured or stapled closure by maintaining a closed environment and removing exudates via the application of negative pressure wound therapy.

hotspot.title: Blockage/Canister Alarm
hotspot.content: A solid yellow LED indicates when the therapy unit detects a blockage or canister is full. An audible leak alarm will also activate.

hotspot.title: Leak Alarm
hotspot.content: A solid yellow LED indicates when the therapy unit detects a significant negative pressure leak. An audible leak alarm will also activate.

hotspot.title: Battery Level Indicator/Power Connected Indicator
hotspot.content: Indicates level of battery charge or when unit is connected to A/C power source.

hotspot.title: Selector Button – Continuous Therapy
hotspot.content: Press to select Continuous or Dynamic Pressure Control therapy mode.

hotspot.title: On/Off Button and Therapy Life Indicators
hotspot.content: Press to turn V.A.C.Via Therapy Unit on/off. Green LED indicator lights display unit is on and number of therapy days left.

hotspot.title: Pressure Setting
hotspot.content: Press to select negative pressure setting of either 75 or 125mmHg. Unit default negative pressure setting is 125mmHg.

hotspot.title: Alarm Audio Pause
hotspot.content: Press to audio pause the alarm for 2 minutes; alarm will resume if alarm condition has not been resolved.

pages.title: Videos
pages.content:
The following videos are intended for healthcare professional use only. Patients viewing these videos are encouraged to contact their physicians for information about KCI products and therapies and whether it may be right for them.

The videos are intended as informational only and are not intended as in-service or training videos. Prior to use of any KCI product or therapy, it is important for the provider to consult the treating physician and read and understand all Instructions for Use, including Safety Information, Dressing Application Instructions, Device Instructions and Clinical Guidelines. KCI recommends that clinicians participate in device in-service and training prior to use.

pages.title: V.A.C.Via Application Video
pages.content:
Demonstrates basic application technique of the single patient use V.A.C.Via™ Negative Pressure Wound Therapy System.

FOR HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONALS ONLY

The V.A.C.Via™ Therapy System is indicated for use in acute, extended and home care settings. It is intended for patients with chronic, acute, traumatic, sub acute and dehisced wounds, partial - thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure or venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

The V.A.C.Via™ Therapy System in not intended for use on patients with malignancy in the wound, untreated osteomyelitis, non-enteric and explored fistulas, or necrotic tissue with eschar present. Do not place foam dressings of the V.A.C.Via™ Therapy System directly in contact with exposed blood vessels, anastomotic sites, organs or nerves.

This video is intended to be used in conjunction with the V.A.C.Via™ Therapy System Instruction for Use (IFU). It is not intended as an alternative to the IFU. When viewing this video, please refer to the V.A.C.Via™ IFU for details on applying the device, as well as important safety information. A copy of the IFU can be obtained from your KCI representative or at www.VACVia.com.

For more information about the V.A.C.Via™ Therapy System call
1-800-275-4524
www.VACVia.com

Follow local institutional protocols for infection control and waste disposal procedures. Local protocols should be based on the applicable local government environmental regulations.

NOTE: Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for the V.A.C.Via™ Therapy System. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application. Rx only.

The information in this video is intended for healthcare professionals only. Patients who may have viewed this video and have questions should consult with their healthcare providers regarding specific medical conditions and treatments, as well as the information provided in the video.

pages.title: Recycling
pages.content:
Recycle Single-Use Negative Pressure Therapy Units AT NO COST TO YOU

KCI has partnered with a medical waste management company for the safe return and recycling of V.A.C.Via™ Negative Pressure Therapy Systems and Prevena™ Incision Management Systems.

Contact the KCI National Contact Center at 1-800-275-4524 to request the specially designed, safe, postage-paid shipping container provided by KCI.

If you prefer not to recycle, please check with your healthcare provider for disposal instructions.

pages.title: ActiV.A.C.
pages.content:
ActiV.A.C.®

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product information for use prior to application.

Negative Pressure Therapy System

The ActiV.A.C.® Therapy System is the portable KCI Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT) System. It uses SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology (Therapeutic Regulated Accurate Care) to assure the prescribed negative pressure setting is delivered to the wound site. The ActiV.A.C.® Therapy System is:

  • Specifically designed for patients in the ambulatory environment with wounds that require a 300mL canister.
  • Designed with the clinician and patient in mind.
    • For the clinician, the ActiV.A.C.® Therapy System makes V.A.C.® Therapy easy to use by providing enhanced features such as Seal Check™ and Therapy History Reports.
    • For the patient, the ActiV.A.C.® Therapy System is lightweight, has a 14-hour battery life and comes with a carrying case that allows the therapy unit to be worn in a variety of ways.
  • Software-controlled advanced wound care technology can be used on a variety of chronic and acute wounds and can be readily integrated into the clinician’s wound healing practice, helping to optimize patient care.

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
For the outpatient/home care setting, the features of this ergonomically designed therapy unit include

  • Lightweight (2.4 pounds)
  • Small size with a low profile design that can be worn close to the body
  • Easy-to-use, single-touch therapy on/off operation
  • Alarm notifications that are easy to recognize and correct
  • Easy, quick release 300mL canister
  • 14-hour battery
  • SensaT.R.A.C.™ technology monitors and maintains target pressure.
  • A carrying case hides the tubing
  • Quiet operation
  • Includes USB port for convenient data download

Seal Check™ Feature
Designed to help clinicians and patients identify and troubleshoot negative pressure leaks, Seal Check™ provides:

  • Instant Feedback. Audio and visual cues are delivered in real-time, allowing easy location of dressing leaks.
  • Enhanced Therapy Confidence. A proper seal helps provide accurate delivery of prescribed therapy for wound healing.
  • Possible Reduction of Unscheduled Visits. Patients can troubleshoot dressing leaks themselves. Easier for clinicians to help troubleshoot problems over the phone.

Simplified Touch Screen
Enhanced, simplified control functions:

  • Easy Navigation. Features a full-color interface with intuitive touch screen controls.
  • Simplified Patient Mode. Control functions designed specifically for patients are easy to use and understand.
  • Reduced Training. Shares common control functions with the InfoV.A.C.® Therapy System for easier training.

Settings Guide
Recommended therapy settings and pressure ranges are pre-programmed into the unit based on the indicated wound types, allowing for:

  • Easy Set Up. With pre-programmed settings by wound type, clinicians can initiate therapy quickly and efficiently.
  • Simple Usage. Intuitive control functions make it easier to use, especially for clinicians who are not as familiar with V.A.C.® Therapy.

Therapy History Reports
With its built-in ability to store and track therapy data, healthcare professionals can:

  • Document Patient Compliance with V.A.C.® Therapy. Monitors therapy usage, settings, durations, and dressing and canister changes to help ensure patients are receiving the prescribed course of therapy.
  • Stay Informed. Information can be downloaded to a USB flash drive or SD memory card.

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The ActiV.A.C.® Negative Pressure Wound Therapy Systems are integrated wound management systems for use in acute, extended and home care settings.

When used on open wounds, they are intended to create an environment that promotes wound healing by secondary or tertiary (delayed primary) intention by preparing the wound bed for closure, reducing edema, promoting granulation tissue formation and perfusion, and by removing exudate and infectious material. Open wound types include: chronic, acute, traumatic, subacute and dehisced wounds, partial-thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure or venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

When used on closed surgical incisions, they are also intended to manage the environment of surgical incisions that continue to drain following sutured or stapled closure by maintaining a closed environment and removing exudates via the application of negative pressure wound therapy.

pages.title: V.A.C. Freedom
pages.content:
V.A.C. Freedom®

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product information for use prior to application.

Negative Pressure Therapy System

The V.A.C. Freedom® Therapy System is a portable KCI Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT) System that uses SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology (Therapeutic Regulated Accurate Care) to assure the prescribed negative pressure setting is delivered to the wound site. The V.A.C. Freedom® Therapy System is:

  • Specifically designed for the patient in the long-term care environment with wounds that require a 300mL canister.
  • Lightweight and portable so patients can receive NPWT during rehabilitation and daily living activities in a long-term care facility. The V.A.C. Freedom® Therapy System has a 12-hour battery life and comes with a carrying case.
  • Software-controlled advanced wound care technology can be used on a variety of chronic and acute wounds and can be readily integrated into the clinician’s wound healing practice, helping to optimize patient care.

mp_subtitle: Long Term Care Portable NPWT Unit

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
For the long-term care setting, the features of this ergonomically designed therapy unit include

  • Lightweight (3.6 pounds)
  • Small size
  • Easy-to-use, single-touch therapy on/off operation
  • Alarm notifications are easy to recognize and correct
  • Easy, quick release 300mL canister
  • 12-hour battery
  • SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology monitors and maintains target pressure

Therapy Settings Screen

  • Provides clinicians instant access to therapy settings

On Screen User Guide

  • Provides clinicians instant access to quick operating instructions and caregiver’s guide overview

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The V.A.C. Freedom® Negative Pressure Wound Therapy Systems are integrated wound management systems for use in acute, extended and home care settings.

When used on open wounds, they are intended to create an environment that promotes wound healing by secondary or tertiary (delayed primary) intention by preparing the wound bed for closure, reducing edema, promoting granulation tissue formation and perfusion, and by removing exudate and infectious material. Open wound types include: chronic, acute, traumatic, subacute and dehisced wounds, partial-thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure or venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

When used on closed surgical incisions, they are also intended to manage the environment of surgical incisions that continue to drain following sutured or stapled closure by maintaining a closed environment and removing exudates via the application of negative pressure wound therapy.

pages.title: V.A.C.Ulta
pages.content:
V.A.C.Ulta™ Therapy System

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy is available only with the V.A.C.Ulta™ Therapy System.

The V.A.C.Ulta™ Therapy System is an integrated wound management system that provides:

V.A.C.® Therapy (Negative Pressure Wound Therapy)
Provides all of the valued benefits from previous generations of V.A.C.® Therapy Systems with new more advanced features.

V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy (Instillation Therapy)
V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy is negative pressure wound therapy (V.A.C.® Therapy) coupled with controlled delivery and removal of topical wound irrigation solutions and suspensions over the wound bed (instillation) (also commonly referred to as NPWTi in scientific journals). V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy:

  • Is for patients who would benefit from vacuum assisted drainage and controlled delivery of topical wound solutions over the wound bed.
  • Provides selectable times for solution delivery rate and hold time.
  • Alternates NPWT with Instillation Therapy.

Consider V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy for wounds that would benefit from instillation therapy, such as:

  • Contaminated wounds with instillation of topical wound cleansers
  • Infected wounds with instillation of appropriate topical wound solutions; these wounds also benefit from the removal of infectious materials in the V.A.C.® Therapy cycle.

V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy combines the benefits of V.A.C.® Therapy with automated topical wound solution distribution and removal.

  • Cleanses the wound with instillation of topical wound cleansers in a consistent, controlled manner
  • Treats the wound with the instillation of appropriate topical antimicrobial and antiseptic solutions and the removal of infectious material
  • Heals the wound and prepares for primary or secondary closure

mp_subtitle: Inpatient NPWT Unit with Instillation Therapy Option

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
V.A.C.® Therapy:

Enhanced Graphic User Interface

  • Intuitive touch screen menu.
  • Simple therapeutic programming.

Customized Pressure Algorithms

  • Continuous negative pressure (from -25 to-200mmHg).
  • Dynamic Pressure Control™ - the evolution of intermittent therapy to maintain minimum negative pressure levels (-25mmHg) in the wound bed at all times.

Designed for use with the following trusted V.A.C.® Therapy System accessories:

  • SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology provides continuous feedback for enhanced negative pressure accuracy.
  • V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressings help promote granulation tissue formation and facilitate exudate removal.
  • V.A.C.® Canisters collect exudate and infectious materials.
  • Seal Check™ Detector offers instant feedback to help identify leaks.

V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy

  • Consider V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy for wounds that would benefit from instillation therapy, such as:
    • Contaminated wounds with instillation of topical wound cleansers
    • Infected wounds with instillation of appropriate topical wound solutions; these wounds also benefit from the removal of infectious materials in the V.A.C.® Therapy cycle.
  • Provides automated and controlled delivery of topical wound solutions via an infusion pump.
  • FILL ASSIST tool helps determine the correct instillation volume.
  • DRESSING SOAK tool instills topical wound solutions into the wound for easier dressing removal and increased patient comfort.
  • Compatible with existing V.A.C.® Therapy Dressings as well as with new dressings designed for optimal instillation therapy that provide even distribution and removal of wound solutions across the wound bed.
  • V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Dressing promotes granulation tissue formation and is appropriate for wounds when using V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy. V.A.C. VeraFlo Cleanse™ Dressing allows flexibility in addressing wounds with complex geometries and is also appropriate for wounds when using V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy.

Bench and Preclinical studies showed:

  • In an in vitro study, V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy provided contained controlled wound irrigation without bacterial aerosolization compared to standard manual cleansing techniques that demonstrated significant bacterial aerosolization 6 inches from the simulated wound site (p<0.05).1
  • In a porcine study with saline instillation: 7 days of V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy with saline using V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Dressings showed a 43% increase in wound fill compared to NPWT using V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressings (p<0.05). V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy cycles utilized a 5-minute soak time followed by 2.5 hours of V.A.C.® Therapy. These results have not yet been confirmed in human studies.

1 Allen D, Bondre IL, McNulty AK. Comparison of bacterial aerosolization during wound cleansing via two methods: Pulsed lavage and normal saline instillation in conjuction with negative pressure wound therapy. Wound Repair and Regeneration. 18[2], A41. 3-1-2010.

2 Lessing C, Slack P, Hong KZ, et al. Negative pressure wound therapy with controlled saline instillation (NPWTi): dressing properties and granulation response in vivo. Wounds. 2011 October 1;23(10):309-19.

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The V.A.C.Ulta™ Negative Pressure Wound Therapy System is an integrated wound management system that provides Negative Pressure Wound Therapy with an instillation option.

  • Negative Pressure Wound Therapy in the absence of instillation is intended to create an environment that promotes wound healing by secondary or tertiary (delayed primary) intention by preparing the wound bed for closure, reducing edema, promoting granulation tissue formation and perfusion, and by removing exudate and infectious material.
  • The instillation option is indicated for patients who would benefit from vacuum assisted drainage and controlled delivery of topical wound treatment solutions and suspensions over the wound bed.

The V.A.C.Ulta™ Negative Pressure Wound Therapy System with and without instillation is indicated for patients with chronic, acute, traumatic, sub-acute and dehisced wounds, partial thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure and venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

pages.title: Videos
pages.content:
The following videos are intended for healthcare professional use only. Patients viewing these videos are encouraged to contact their physicians for information about KCI products and therapies and whether it may be right for them.

The videos are intended as informational only and are not intended as in-service or training videos. Prior to use of any KCI product or therapy, it is important for the provider to consult the treating physician and read and understand all Instructions for Use, including Safety Information, Dressing Application Instructions, Device Instructions and Clinical Guidelines. KCI recommends that clinicians participate in device in-service and training prior to use.

pages.title: V.A.C.Ulta Application Video
pages.content:
Demonstrates the basic application technique of the V.A.C.Ulta™ Negative Pressure Wound Therapy System.

The V.A.C.Ulta™ Negative Pressure Wound Therapy System is an integrated wound management system that provides Negative Pressure Wound Therapy with an Instillation Therapy Option. This video is intended to be used in conjunction with the V.A.C.Ulta™ Therapy System labeling and instructions. When viewing this video, please refer to the V.A.C.Ulta™ System labeling and instructions for details on applying the system, as well as safety information. A copy of the labeling and instructions can be obtained from your KCI representative or at www.VACUlta.com.

The information in this video is intended for healthcare professionals only. Patients who may have viewed this video should consult with their healthcare providers regarding their specific medical conditions and treatments, as well as the information provided in the video.

NOTE: Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for the V.A.C.Ulta™ Therapy System. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application. Rx only.

V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy will result in pauses of negative pressure wound therapy. Do not use V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy over unstable structures, such as unstable chest wall or non-intact fascia; on patients at increased risk of bleeding or with highly exudating wounds; on flaps, grafts, or wounds with acute enteric fistulae; or on wounds open to the thoracic or abdominal cavity.

V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy is not intended for use with cellular or acellular bioengineered tissues.

Due to the potential for disruption of clots or dilution of clotting factors, do not use V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy where hemostatic agents have been used in the wound bed.

For more information about the V.A.C.Ulta™ Therapy System, call
1-800-275-4524 or visit www.VACUlta.com

pages.title: Specifications
pages.content:
Feature Description
Weight: 3.35kg (7.4 lbs with a 500cc empty canister and no solution bag)
Dimensions: 217mm x 260mm x 191mm (8.55in x 10.25in X 7.5in)
   
Electrical Data (Power Supply)
  • Voltage 100 - 240 VAC
  • Frequency 50Hz - 60Hz
  • Power 60WIEC Classification
  • V.A.C.Ulta™ Therapy Unit
  • Continuous Operation
  • Type BF Applied Part
  • Class II or internally powered equipment
  • IPX1
   
Power Supply  
  • Class I Equipment
  • Ordinary Equipment
  
Battery Type: Custom Lithium Battery
Battery Life: Approximately 6 hours
Battery Recharge: Approximately 4 hours
   
Environmental Conditions  
Transport and Storage Temperature Range -20ºC to +60ºC (-4°F to 140°F)
Operational Temperature Range +10ºC to +30ºC (50ºF to 86°F)
Relative Humidity Range l0% to 85% non-condensing
Barometric pressure Range 700 hPa to 1060 hPa
   
Electromagnetic Interference
Although this equipment conforms with the intent of the directive 20041108/EC in relation to Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC), all electrical equipment may produce interference. If interference is suspected, move equipment away from sensitive devices or contact the manufacturer. Portable and mobile RF communications equipment can affect medical electrical equipment. Radios, cell phones and similar devices may affect this equipment and should be kept at least 6.5 feet (2 meters) away from the equipment. Please refer to V.A.C.Ulta™ Product Manual for specific electromagnetic interference guidelines.
*Specifications subject to change without notice

pages.title: WhiteFoam
pages.content:
V.A.C.® WhiteFoam Dressings

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

The V.A.C.® WhiteFoam Dressing is a versatile wound dressing that:

  • Helps promote flap and graft take
  • May be used over split thickness skin grafts
  • Has a higher tensile strength than V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing that allows for easier removal with less tearing

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
• Less adherent material than V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing for use in bolstering skin grafts
  • Higher tensile strength than V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing makes it easier to place and remove with less tearing
  • Increased density helps restrict in-growth of granulation tissue for a more comfortable dressing change
  • Helps protect delicate underlying structures in wounds, such as tendon and bone
  • Pre-moistened with sterile water

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The ActiV.A.C.®, InfoV.A.C.®, V.A.C. ATS®, and V.A.C. Freedom® Negative Pressure Wound Therapy Systems are integrated wound management systems for use in acute, extended and home care settings.

When used on open wounds, they are intended to create an environment that promotes wound healing by secondary or tertiary (delayed primary) intention by preparing the wound bed for closure, reducing edema, promoting granulation tissue formation and perfusion, and by removing exudate and infectious material. Open wound types include: chronic, acute, traumatic, subacute and dehisced wounds, partial-thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure or venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

When used on closed surgical incisions, they are also intended to manage the environment of surgical incisions that continue to drain following sutured or stapled closure by maintaining a closed environment and removing exudates via the application of negative pressure wound therapy.

pages.title: VeraFlo / VeraFlo Cleanse
pages.content:
V.A.C. VeraFlo™ / VeraFlo Cleanse™ Dressings

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy is available only with the V.A.C.Ulta™ Therapy System. For more information, visit the V.A.C.Ulta™ Therapy System product page on this app.

V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Dressing is recommended for open wounds, including wounds with shallow undermining or tunnel areas where the distal aspect is visible.

V.A.C. VeraFlo Cleanse™ Dressing allows the clinician flexibility in addressing wounds with varying geometries.

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Dressing:

  • Promotes granulation tissue formation
  • Is appropriate for wounds when using V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy.

V.A.C. VeraFlo Cleanse™ Dressing:

  • Provides even distribution and removal of wound solutions across the wound bed.
  • Is customizable for a variety of wound geometries

Preclinical testing compared the V.A.C. VeraFlo Cleanse™ Dressing to the V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Dressing.

Bench testing conducted in accordance with ASTM 3574-08 physical properties tests demonstrated the following tensile and tear strength results:

Property Result
Tensile strength  
Wet (saline) conditions V.A.C. VeraFlo Cleanse™ Dressing had approximately 3 times greater tensile strength than V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Dressing.
Dry conditions V.A.C. VeraFlo Cleanse™ Dressing had approximately 2.5 times greater tensile strength than V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Dressing.
   
Tear strength  
Wet (saline) conditions V.A.C. VeraFlo Cleanse™ Dressing had approximately 3 times greater tear strength than V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Dressing.
Dry conditions V.A.C. VeraFlo Cleanse™ Dressing had approximately 3 times greater tear strength than V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Dressing.

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The V.A.C.Ulta™ Negative Pressure Wound Therapy System (V.A.C.Ulta™ Therapy System) is an integrated wound therapy system that can deliver either:

  • V.A.C. VeraFlo™ Therapy (Instillation), which consists of negative pressure wound therapy (V.A.C.® Therapy) coupled with controlled delivery and drainage of topical wound irrigation treatment solutions and suspensions over the wound bed.
OR
 
  • V.A.C.® Therapy, which consists of negative pressure wound therapy alone.

pages.title: Simplace / Simplace EX
pages.content:
V.A.C.® Simplace™ and Simplace™ EX Dressings

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

Featuring V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Spiral Dressing and a 3M™ Tegaderm™ Dressing designed exclusively for use with V.A.C.® Therapy

V.A.C.® Simplace™ Dressings have been specifically designed to simplify the V.A.C.® Therapy dressing placement process, including bridge application. Clinicians can apply V.A.C.® Therapy Dressings in a few steps with this easy-to-use kit.

V.A.C.® Simplace™ EX Dressings
Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.
Featuring V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Spiral Dressing and V.A.C.® Drape designed exclusively for use with V.A.C.® Therapy.

V.A.C.® Simplace™ Dressings have been specifically designed to simplify the V.A.C.® Therapy dressing placement process, including bridge application. Clinicians can apply V.A.C.® Therapy Dressings in a few steps with this easy-to-use kit.

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing

  • Helps to promote healing by facilitating granulation tissue formation
  • Spiral-cut foam is simple to size
  • Can be torn - scissors may not be necessary
  • Design allows for easy bridging

Dressing Drape
3M™ Tegaderm™ Dressing (V.A.C.® Simplace™ Dressing)

  • Designed exclusively for use with V.A.C.® Therapy
  • Provides a moist wound healing environment
  • Barrier to outside contaminants
  • Easy to apply with few steps

V.A.C.® Drape and Precut V.A.C.® Drape Strips (V.A.C.® Simplace™ EX Dressing)

  • Designed exclusively for use with V.A.C.® Therapy
  • Helps provide a moist wound healing environment
  • Barrier to outside contaminants
  • Precut V.A.C.® Drape strips provide easier application and fewer steps for bridging

SensaT.R.A.C.™ Pad and Tubing

  • Independently monitor target negative pressure at the wound site and helps provide accurate therapy delivery
  • Pad helps reduce tubing blocks and false alarms through enhanced fluid dynamics
  • Pad design facilitates patient comfort with a lower profile

V.A.C.® Foam Quantity Ruler

  • Removable labels for convenient foam count documentation

Few Steps, Fast Application. With V.A.C.® Simplace Dressings, your V.A.C.® Therapy Dressing application is easier than ever.
3M and Tegaderm are trademarks of 3M Company

pages.title: Simplace Dressing Application
pages.content:
Demonstrates basic application technique of the V.A.C.® Simplace™ Dressing.

The V.A.C.® Therapy System is indicated for patients with chronic, acute, traumatic, subacute and dehisced wounds, partial thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure, or venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

This video is intended for clinicians. Prior to use of the V.A.C.® Therapy System, consult detailed product instructions and important prescribing information contained in the KCI V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines and the device (or disposables) specific user's guide.

Additional safety information specific to the V.A.C.® Therapy System is available at the end of this video. Contact your local KCI representative or call 1-800-275-4524 if you have any questions before initiating therapy.

If you are performing a dressing change, be sure to identify the number of foam pieces previously placed in the wound. Ensure that you remove all the foam pieces.

V.A.C.® Therapy is contraindicated for: Patients with malignancy in the wound, untreated osteomyelitis, non-enteric and unexplored fistulas and necrotic tissue with eschar present. After debridement of necrotic tissue and complete removal of eschar, V.A.C.® Therapy may be used after hemostasis has been achieved.

V.A.C.® Therapy foam dressings should not be placed directly in contact with exposed blood vessels, anastomotic sites, organs, or nerves. Do not place any foam dressing into blind/unexplored tunnels. The V.A.C.® WhiteFoam Dressing may be used with explored tunnels.

Instructions for Use and Safety Information: As with any device, it is important to read and understand the detailed instructions for use and safety information (including information on bleeding, exposed vessels and organs, and infection) applicable to your V.A.C.® Therapy unit and dressing application that can be found within the therapy unit, disposables carton or in the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines (www.KCI1.com).

These sources provide information concerning the proper application of all V.A.C.® Therapy Dressings, including advanced applications and techniques.

If you have product questions, please contact KCI at 1-800-275-4524 option #3. KCI offers device training upon request.

pages.title: GranuFoam
pages.content:
V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

Designed to adapt to irregular wound contours, V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressings allow caregivers to use V.A.C.® Therapy for a wide variety of chronic, acute and sub-acute wounds, from simple to complex, and hard-to-reach, inconveniently located wounds.

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressings
  • Multiple shapes and sizes to accommodate diverse wounds
  • Flexible design adapts to the contours of deep and irregularly shaped wounds
  • Helps promote formation of granulation tissue
  • Open pore structure (400 – 600 microns) helps provide uniform distribution of negative pressure at the wound site
  • Hydrophobic construction helps exudate removal

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The ActiV.A.C.®, InfoV.A.C.®, V.A.C. ATS®, and V.A.C. Freedom® Negative Pressure Wound Therapy Systems are integrated wound management systems for use in acute, extended and home care settings.

When used on open wounds, they are intended to create an environment that promotes wound healing by secondary or tertiary (delayed primary) intention by preparing the wound bed for closure, reducing edema, promoting granulation tissue formation and perfusion, and by removing exudate and infectious material. Open wound types include: chronic, acute, traumatic, subacute and dehisced wounds, partial-thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure or venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

When used on closed surgical incisions, they are also intended to manage the environment of surgical incisions that continue to drain following sutured or stapled closure by maintaining a closed environment and removing exudates via the application of negative pressure wound therapy.

carousel.title: Step 1
carousel.content:
Assess wound size and type.

Prepare wound bed appropriately.

carousel.title: Step 2
carousel.content:
Cut dressing to size.

Do not cut dressing over wound as this could result in foam particles falling into the wound.

carousel.title: Step 3
carousel.content:
Place dressing in wound.

Document the number of foam pieces used. Labels are provided on the Foam Quantity Ruler for use on the dressing, tubing, and in the patient’s chart.

carousel.title: Step 4
carousel.content:
Trim drape to size.

Peel back one side of Layer 1 and place adhesive side down over wound. Remove the remaining side of Layer 1, the green striped stabilization Layer 2 and the perforated Blue Handling Tab(s).

carousel.title: Step 5
carousel.content:
SensaT.R.A.C.™ Pad Application.

Identify application site for SensaT.R.A.C.™ Pad.

carousel.title: Step 6
carousel.content:
Pinch drape and cut a 2.5cm round hole.

Consider the diameter of a quarter for size reference.

carousel.title: Step 7
carousel.content: Remove backing Layers 1 and 2 from SensaT.R.A.C.™ Pad.

carousel.title: Step 8
carousel.content:
Place SensaT.R.A.C.™ Pad opening directly over hole.

Pull blue tab to remove stabilization layer. Record date and number of foam pieces in the wound on the drape and in the patient record.

carousel.title: Step 9
carousel.content: Connect SensaT.R.A.C.™ Pad tubing to canister tubing.

carousel.title: Step 10
carousel.content:
Turn on power to V.A.C.® Therapy Unit.

Set to the physician prescribed therapy settings to initiate therapy.

carousel.title: Questions and Information
carousel.content:
For additional, detailed information, please refer to specific dressing instructions for use (contained in disposables cartons) and the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines. These sources provide information concerning the proper application of all V.A.C.® Therapy Dressings including advanced applications and techniques. If you have product questions, please contact KCI at 1-800-275-4524.

NOTE: Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

CAUTION: Federal Law restricts this device to sale/rental by or on the order of a physician.

pages.title: GranuFoam Silver
pages.content:
V.A.C. GranuFoam Silver® Dressing

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

The only silver foam dressing specifically engineered for the V.A.C.® Therapy System. Combines the demonstrated benefits of V.A.C.® Therapy with the antimicrobial benefits of silver.

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
Direct and Complete Contact
The only silver dressing that allows the V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing pores to come in direct contact with the wound, eliminating the need for additional silver dressing layers that may influence negative pressure transduction and granulation tissue formation.

Easy to Use
One simple step: Combines the benefits of V.A.C.® Therapy and silver in one dressing, eliminating the need to add an adjunct silver layer.

Uniform Distribution of Silver
Micro-bonded metallic silver is uniformly distributed throughout the dressing, providing exposure of the wound bed to silver, even after sizing.

Effective Protection
Based on in vitro antimicrobial testing, provides an effective barrier to bacterial penetration. Results show that the silver ions reduce the concentration of aerobic, gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria, which may help reduce infections in wounds.

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The ActiV.A.C.®, InfoV.A.C.®, V.A.C. ATS®, and V.A.C. Freedom® Negative Pressure Wound Therapy Systems are integrated wound management systems for use in acute, extended and home care settings.

When used on open wounds, they are intended to create an environment that promotes wound healing by secondary or tertiary (delayed primary) intention by preparing the wound bed for closure, reducing edema, promoting granulation tissue formation and perfusion, and by removing exudate and infectious material. Open wound types include: chronic, acute, traumatic, subacute and dehisced wounds, partial-thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure or venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

When used on closed surgical incisions, they are also intended to manage the environment of surgical incisions that continue to drain following sutured or stapled closure by maintaining a closed environment and removing exudates via the application of negative pressure wound therapy.

The V.A.C. GranuFoam Silver® Dressing is an effective barrier to bacterial penetration and may help reduce infection in the above wound types.

pages.title: GranuFoam Bridge / Bridge XG
pages.content:
V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge and Bridge XG Dressings

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

Designed for the busy clinician, the V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge & the V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge XG Dressings place the SensaT.R.A.C.™ Pad away from pressure sensitive areas at risk for skin breakdown. The V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge Dressings:

  • Simplify dressing application, make bridging easy, and allow V.A.C.® Therapy to be provided in conjunction with other adjunctive therapies such as compression or off-loading modalities.
  • GranuFoam™ Bridge is ideal for use with diabetic foot wounds requiring off-loading therapy. It helps improve mobility, allowing patients to resume activities of daily living, and facilitates patient transition to a non-acute care setting with an off-loading boot and V.A.C.® Therapy.
  • The V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge XG contains additional GranuFoam™ Dressing making it suitable for bridging larger wounds, such as venous leg ulcers requiring compression therapy and pressure ulcers.

*Off-loading devices are not offered by KCI. Consult treating physicians on use of off-loading with V.A.C. Therapy.

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content:
This easy-to-use guide is intended to help clinicians conveniently apply the V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge Dressing for use with off-loading devices.

V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge Dressing Components:

  • V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge — includes moisture wicking layer and integrated SensaT.R.A.C.™ Pad
  • Perforated V.A.C.® Drape
  • Pre-cut V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing
  • Disposable ruler

V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge Dressing Application Steps

Prep Steps:

Separate the V.A.C.® Drape into its components by tearing along the green lines. Components include:
  • A pre-sized drape with pre-cut hole
  • Half-sheet drape
  • 5 V.A.C.® Drape strips for securing the V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge

Separate the pre-cut V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing into its components. Components include:
  • 3 circular V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing pieces
  • Two additional V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing pieces

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content:
1. Select a piece of V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing.

Tip: Choose a piece slightly larger than the wound and trim to fit.

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content: 2. Place the selected V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing piece into the wound.

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content:
3. Align the pre-cut hole of the V.A.C.® Drape over the wound. Trim to fit as necessary, allowing for a 3 to 5cm border.

Tip: If using the half sheet of V.A.C.® Drape that does not include the pre-cut hole, cut at least a 2.5cm hole to expose the V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing.

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content: 4. Once the V.A.C.® Drape has been sized, remove both halves of the layer marked with the number "1" to expose the adhesive.

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content:
5. Place the V.A.C.® Drape adhesive side down over the wound.

Tip: A smooth and wrinkle-free drape helps prevent dressing leaks.

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content: 6. Remove the layer marked with the number "2" and the blue handling bars.

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content: 7. Determine the position of the bridge considering the location of the wound, footwear that is to be worn, and any other patient considerations. The bridge should not be placed over bony prominences.

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content: 8. Once the placement of the bridge is determined, it can now be secured. Remove the white tab from the bridge end, exposing the adhesive. Align the pre-cut hole on the bridge with the hole on the V.A.C.® Drape and press firmly to ensure the bridge interface is smooth and wrinkle-free.

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content:
9. Beginning near the ankle and moving proximally up the leg, secure the bridge using the pre-cut V.A.C.® Drape strips.

Tip: Care should be taken to ensure that the secured bridge does not impede the range of motion of the foot or create pressure points.

carousel.title: V.A.C. GranuFoam Bridge Dressing Application Tips
carousel.content:
10. If the length of the bridge requires adjustment, position the bridge in a Z-fold pattern and secure with a pre-cut V.A.C.® Drape strip.

Tip: Always ensure that the SensaT.R.A.C.® Pad or Z-fold is positioned outside of any off-loading boot or shoe.

IMPORTANT NOTES:

  • For vertical bridge placement on moderately to highly- exudating wounds, the V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Bridge Dressing should not be used for settings below 125mmHg.
  • Document the number of foam pieces used. Labels are provided on the Foam Quantity Ruler for use on the dressing, tubing, and in the patient’s chart.
  • As with any medical device, clinicians should refer to Instructions for Use and V.A.C.® Therapy safety information prior to use.

Indication:
The ActiV.A.C.®, InfoV.A.C.®, V.A.C. ATS®, and V.A.C. Freedom® Therapy Systems are integrated wound management systems for use in acute, extended and home care settings.

They are indicated for patients with chronic, acute, traumatic, subacute and dehisced wounds, partial-thickness burns, ulcers (such as diabetic, pressure or venous insufficiency), flaps and grafts.

This video is intended for clinicians.

Prior to use of the V.A.C.® Therapy System, consult and follow detailed safety and product information contained in the KCI V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines and the device (or disposables) specific labeling.

Resources for safety information specific to the V.A.C.® Therapy System are available at the end of this video.

If you have any questions before initiating therapy, contact your local KCI representative, call 1-800-275-4524, or go to www.KCI1.com.

V.A.C.® Therapy is contraindicated for:
Patients with malignancy in the wound, untreated osteomyelitis, non-enteric and unexplored fistulas and necrotic tissue with eschar present.

After debridement of necrotic tissue and complete removal of eschar, V.A.C.® Therapy may be used.

V.A.C.® Therapy's foam dressings should not be placed directly in contact with exposed blood vessels, anastomotic sites, organs, or nerves.

Instructions for Use and Safety Information:
As with any device, it is important to read and understand the detailed instructions for use and safety information (including information on bleeding, exposed vessels and organs, and infection) applicable to your V.A.C.® Therapy unit and dressing application that can be found with the therapy unit, disposables carton or in the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines (www.kci1.com).

These sources provide information concerning the proper application of all V.A.C.® Therapy Dressings including advanced applications and techniques.

If you have product questions, please contact KCI at 1-800-275-4524 option #5.

KCI offers device training upon request.

pages.title: SensaT.R.A.C. Technology
pages.content:
What is V.A.C.® Therapy?
Since its introduction in 1996, V.A.C.® Therapy has changed the way wounds are healed. With more published clinical evidence than any other form of Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT), V.A.C.® Therapy delivers proven clinical and economic outcomes. V.A.C.® Therapy has been selected as the treatment of choice for more than 7 million wounds treated worldwide.

V.A.C.® (Vacuum Assisted Closure®) Therapy is a system that uses controlled continuous or intermittent negative pressure (vacuum) to create an environment that promotes wound healing by secondary or tertiary (delayed primary) intention by:

  • Preparing the wound bed for closure
  • Reducing edema
  • Promoting granulation tissue formation and perfusion
  • Removing exudate and infectious material

SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology - An Essential Component of V.A.C.® Therapy

The ONLY NPWT system that monitors pressure at the wound site and adjusts accordingly, patented KCI SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology ensures the prescribed negative pressure is maintained for optimal healing outcomes.

Why SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology?

  • Movement of wound fluid against gravity, as well as viscosity of the exudate in the tubing, influences negative pressure delivery
  • Only the KCI SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology incorporated in all V.A.C.® Therapy devices compensates for pressure variances at the wound site due to patient position, movement and exudate characteristics

An in-vitro study* showed that when a simulated wound model was lowered 36 inches (91cm) below the vacuum pump, the pressure drop was significantly less (p=<.005) using V.A.C.® Therapy with SensaT.R.A.C.™ and GranuFoam™ Dressing than with NPWT with gauze or NPWT with reticulated open cell foam without the benefit of regulated pressure feedback and control like the KCI SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology.

*McNulty A, Spranger I, Courage J, et al. The Consistent Delivery of Negative Pressure to Wounds Using Reticulated, Open Cell Foam and Regulated Pressure Feedback. WOUNDS 2010;22(5):114-120

mp_subtitle: An Essential Component of V.A.C. Therapy

carousel.title: SensaT.R.A.C. Pad
carousel.content:
• Distributes negative pressure to individual sensing lumens
  • Helps reduce tubing blocks and false alarms through enhanced fluid dynamics
  • Facilitates patient comfort with a low profile design

carousel.title: SensaT.R.A.C. Tubing
carousel.content:
• Efficiently draws exudate away from the wound through the large inner lumen
  • Independently monitors target pressure at the wound through outer sensing lumens
  • Allows for secure and convenient tubing connections

carousel.title: Monitoring Software
carousel.content:
• Continuously regulates negative pressure feedback
  • Maintains prescribed negative pressure at the wound site by adjusting pump output
  • Safety alarms alert caregivers if target pressure is not met or therapy is interrupted

carousel.title: In Vitro Study
carousel.content:
An in vitro study* showed that pressure drop at the simulated wound was significantly less (p<0.05) using V.A.C.® Therapy with SensaT.R.A.C.™ and V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing than using NPWT with gauze or NPWT with reticulated open cell foam, without the benefit of regulated pressure feedback and control from SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology.

To calculate fold change, values were compared to control levels of pressure drop for V.A.C.® Therapy with SensaT.R.A.C.™ Technology and V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressings. Normalized vertical pressure drop was measured with a surrogate wound model 36 inches (91cm) below the vacuum pump. V.A.C.® Therapy unit was set to -80mmHg to evaluate negative pressure levels used by non-KCI NPWT pumps.

*McNulty A, Spranger I, Courage J, et al. The Consistent Delivery of Negative Pressure to Wounds Using Reticulated, Open Cell Foam and Regulated Pressure Feedback. WOUNDS 2010;22(5):114-120(5):114-120

pages.title: APMA Seal of Acceptance
pages.content:
KCI V.A.C.® Therapy has been awarded the APMA Seal of Acceptance, which recognizes products that have been found to promote quality foot health and be of significant value when used in regular professional treatment.

The Seal is awarded after the Committee on Podiatric Seals, a standing committee of the APMA, scientifically evaluates and determines whether the product allows normal foot function and promotes quality foot health. Evidence of usefulness and safety must be established, either by an appropriately recognized laboratory or clinical investigation, or by the product’s meeting certain physical standards.

Tap the button below to view all of the KCI V.A.C.® Therapy products that have been awarded the Seal of Approval.

ABThera™

Open Abdomen Negative Pressure Therapy System

Specific indications, contraindications, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for KCI products and therapies. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

A temporary abdominal closure system that enables healthcare professionals to take control early in the management of challenging open abdomens, helping to achieve primary fascial closure.

  • Dressing kit enables fast, easy and consistent application over the open abdomen
  • Visceral Protective Layer designed for easy handling and rapid application
  • Perforated Foam allows for quick and easy sizing
  • Designed for use with ABThera™, V.A.C.Ulta™ or InfoV.A.C.® Therapy Units

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
Negative Pressure Therapy Unit

  • Dressing designed for use with the ABThera™, V.A.C.Ulta™ or InfoV.A.C.® Therapy Units
  • Provide continuous negative pressure to remove high volume of exudates
  • Large 500 or 1000mL graduated canisters

ABThera™ Proprietary Fenestrated Visceral Protective Layer with Foam Extensions

  • Allows rapid access for re-entry
  • No sutures required for placement, minimizing fascial damage
  • Provides separation between abdominal wall and viscera, protecting abdominal contents
  • Helps stabilize abdominal content
  • Enhances fluid removal from paracolic gutters

ABThera™ Perforated Foam

  • Negative pressure delivered through the foam provides medial tension which helps minimize fascial retraction and loss of domain

ABThera™ Drape

  • Provides a closed system to help isolate abdominal contents

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The ABThera™ (NPT) System is indicated for temporary bridging of abdominal wall openings where primary closure is not possible and / or repeat abdominal entries are necessary. The Intended Use of this system is for use in open abdominal wounds, with exposed viscera, including but not limited to abdominal compartment syndrome.

The ABThera™ (NPT) System is intended for use in the acute hospital setting (trauma and general or plastic surgery wards). The abdominal dressing will most often be applied in the operating theater.

Contraindications

Patients with open abdominal wounds containing non-enteric unexplored fistulas should not be treated with the ABThera™ (NPT) System.

Protect vital structures with ABThera™ Visceral Protective Layer at all times during therapy. Never place exposed foam material directly in contact with exposed bowel, organs, blood vessels or nerves.

Management of the open abdomen has been documented in case reports and consensus panel literature. Please refer to the References List section at the end of the dressing application instructions.

Warnings

Bleeding: Patients with abdominal wounds must be closely monitored for bleeding as these wounds may contain hidden blood vessels which may not be readily apparent. If sudden or increased bleeding is observed in the dressing, tubing or canister, immediately turn off the ABThera™ (NPT) System, take appropriate measures to stop bleeding, and contact the physician. The ABThera™ (NPT) System is not designed to prevent, minimize or stop bleeding. Hemostasis must be achieved prior to dressing placement.

The following conditions may increase the risk of potentially fatal bleeding.

  • Suturing and / or Anastamoses
  • Trauma
  • Radiation
  • Inadequate wound hemostasis
  • Non-sutured hemostasic agents (for example, bone wax, absorbable gelatin sponge or spray wound sealant) applied in the abdomen may, if disrupted, increase the risk of bleeding. Protect against dislodging such agents.
  • Infection in the abdominal wound may weaken visceral organs and associated vasculature, which may increase susceptibility to bleeding.
  • Use of anticoagulants or platelet aggregation inhibitors.
  • Bone fragments or sharp edges could puncture vessels or abdominal organs. Beware of possible shifting in the relative position of tissues, vessels or organs within the abdominal wound that might increase the possibility of contact with sharp edges.

Intra-abdominal Pressure Monitoring: Laparotomy with the placement of a temporary abdominal closure does not eliminate the possibility of elevation in intra-abdominal pressure (IAP). When using the ABThera™ (NPT) System, IAP monitoring (for clinical or diagnostic signs and symptoms of elevated IAP) should continue as indicated by patient condition, in accordance with institutional clinical practice or guidelines. If intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) or abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) is observed, note intraabdominal pressures and turn off power to the ABThera™ (NPT) System, discontinuing negative pressure. After full expansion of the perforated foam, obtain new intraabdominal pressure measurement. If IAH / ACS persists without negative pressure (and collapse of midline perforated foam), discontinue the use of ABThera™ (NPT) System and address the underlying condition as medically indicated.

Use of Visceral Protective Layer: When using the ABThera™ (NPT) System, ensure that the Open Abdomen Visceral Protective Layer completely covers all exposed viscera and completely separates the viscera from contact with the abdominal wall. Place the Visceral Protective Layer over the omentum or exposed internal organs, and carefully tuck it between the abdominal wall and internal organs, making sure the Visceral Protective Layer completely separates the abdominal wall from the internal organs.

Adhesions and Fistula Development: Formation of adhesions of the viscera to the abdominal wall may reduce the likelihood of fascial reapproximation and increase the risk of fistula development, common complications in patients with exposed viscera.

Infection: Infected abdominal wounds should be monitored closely and may require more frequent dressing changes than non-infected wounds, dependent upon factors such as patient condition, wound condition and treatment goals. Refer to dressing application instructions for details regarding dressing change frequency.

Dressing Placement: Always use an ABThera™ Dressing from a sterile package that has not been opened or damaged. Do not force any dressing component into the wound, as this may damage underlying tissue.

Dressing Removal: The ABThera™ Dressing components are not bioabsorbable. Always remove all dressing components from the abdomen at every dressing change.

Keep Negative Pressure On: Never leave the ABThera™ Dressing in place without active negative pressure for more than two hours. If negative pressure is off for more than two hours, change dressing as shown in these instructions for use. Either apply a new ABThera™ Dressing from an unopened sterile package and restart negative pressure; or apply an alternative dressing.

Defibrillation: Remove adhesive drape from area of defibrillation to prevent inhibition of electrical energy transmission.

Acrylic Adhesive: The ABThera™ Drape has an acrylic adhesive coating, which may present a risk of an adverse reaction in patients who are allergic or hypersensitive to acrylic adhesives. If a patient has a known allergy or hypersensitivity to such adhesives, do not use the ABThera™ Dressing. If any signs of allergic reaction or hypersensitivity develop, such as redness, swelling, rash, urticaria or significant pruritus, discontinue use and ensure appropriate emergency medical treatment. If bronchospasm or more serious signs of allergic reaction appear, remove dressing and ensure appropriate emergency medical intervention.

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) – Therapy Unit: The ABThera™ (NPT) Unit is MR unsafe. Do not take the device into the MR environment.

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) – ABThera™ Dressing: The ABThera™ Dressing can remain on the patient with minimal risk in an MR environment, assuming that use of the ABThera™ (NPT) System is not interrupted for more than two hours; please refer to Keep Negative Pressure On.

Application Setting: ABThera™ Dressing applications and changes should be performed under strict sterile conditions in the surgical suite. If dressing change is performed outside the surgical suite, it must be performed in an environment equipped to address the onset of critical complications (refer to WARNINGS section) and where strict aseptic technique can be utilized.

Precautions

Standard Precautions: To reduce the risk of transmission of bloodborne pathogens, apply standard precautions for infection control with all patients, per institutional protocol, regardless of their diagnosis or presumed infection status. In addition to gloves, use gown and goggles if exposure to body fluids is likely.

Intra-abdominal Packing: When using intra-abdominal packing with the ABThera™ (NPT) System, packing material may be drier than anticipated. Evaluate packing material prior to removal and rehydrate if necessary to prevent adherence or damage to adjacent structures.

Monitor Fluid Output: The ABThera™ Dressing is designed to efficiently remove fluid from the abdominal compartment and to evenly distribute negative pressure. When treating patients with the ABThera™ (NPT) System, the volume of exudate in the canister and tubing should be frequently examined.

Patient Size and Weight: The size and weight of the patient should be considered when prescribing the ABThera™ (NPT) System. Initial lower negative pressure should be considered for certain small or elderly patients who are at risk of fluid depletion or dehydration. Monitor fluid output including the volume of exudate in both the tubing and canister. This therapy has the potential to remove and collect large volumes of fluid. Tubing volume = approximately 25 mL from dressing to canister.

Spinal Cord Injury: In the event a patient experiences autonomic dysreflexia (sudden changes in blood pressure or heart rate in response to stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system), discontinue negative pressure therapy to help minimize sensory stimulation.

Bradycardia: To minimize the risk of bradycardia, the ABThera™ (NPT) System must not be placed in proximity to the vagus nerve.

Enteric Fistula or Leak: When treating an open abdomen where enteric fistulas are present, clinicians should consider the potential for abdominal contamination if effluent is not appropriately isolated or managed.

Protect Periwound Skin:

  • Consider use of a skin preparation product to protect periwound skin. Do not allow foam to overlap onto intact skin. Protect fragile / friable periwound skin with additional drape, hydrocolloid or other transparent film.
  • Multiple layers of the drape may decrease the moisture vapor transmission rate, which may increase the risk of maceration.
  • If any signs of irritation or sensitivity to the drape, foam or tubing assembly appear, discontinue use and consult a physician.
  • To avoid trauma to the periwound skin, do not pull or stretch the drape over the foam dressing during drape application.

If there are any questions regarding the proper placement or usage of the ABThera™ (NPT) System, please contact your local KCI Clinical Representative.

Safety Statement

IMPORTANT: As with any prescription medical device, failure to consult a physician and carefully read and follow all ABThera™ ( NPT) Unit and dressing instructions and safety information prior to each use may lead to improper product performance and the potential for serious or fatal injury. Do not adjust therapy unit settings or perform therapy application without directions from or supervision by the clinical caregiver.
All disposable components of the ABThera™ (NPT) System are for single use only. Re-use of disposable components may result in wound contamination, infection and/or failure of the wound to heal.

hotspot.title: Power and Therapy On/Off Button
hotspot.content: Press to power the ABThera™ Therapy Unit On/Off.

hotspot.title: System Pressure Selection Panel
hotspot.content: Press to select the desired negative pressure setting. A green LED light will indicate selected negative pressure setting.

hotspot.title: System Pressure Indicator Panel
hotspot.content: Indicates the current negative pressure being delivered.

hotspot.title: Blockage/Canister Full Alarm
hotspot.content: An amber LED indicates when the therapy unit detects a blockage or canister is full; and a visual and audible leak alarm will activate.

hotspot.title: Leak Alarm
hotspot.content: An amber LED indicates when the therapy unit detects a significant negative pressure leak, and an audible leak alarm will activate.

hotspot.title: Low Battery Alarm Indicator
hotspot.content: An amber LED indicates when the therapy unit detects a low battery situation, and an audible leak alarm will activate.

hotspot.title: Power Connected Indicator
hotspot.content: Illuminates when the unit is plugged into an A/C power source.

hotspot.title: Audio Pause Button
hotspot.content: Press the Audio Pause Button during an alarm condition to silence the audible alarm for five minutes.
