carousel.title: ABThera Case Study
carousel.content: Temporary Abdominal Closure of Laparostomy Wound Following Inguinal Hernia Repair

carousel.title: PATIENT
carousel.content: An 81-year-old male presented with a permanent gastrostomy tube. Patient’s prior medical history included fascial trauma and several hernia repairs with a history of recurrence.

carousel.title: DIAGNOSIS
carousel.content: Patient was admitted with painful left inguinal hernia. Labs revealed low hemoglobin, hematocrit, and albumin levels, and elevated creatinine, glucose and hepatic enzyme values.

carousel.title: INITIAL TREATMENT
carousel.content: On hospital day 3, the patient was taken to the operating room for laparoscopic repair of a left inguinal hernia. The following day (hospital day 4), a relaparotomy revealed massive intra-abdominal loss of 4000mL of blood. Diffuse intraperitoneal bleeding was uncovered, largely in the omentum. The patient was intubated and antibiotics were administered. The omentum was excised, and no specific area of bleeding was identified in the omentum vasculature. Abdominal lavage was performed, and the abdomen was left open for re-exploration and to prevent potential abdominal compartment syndrome.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA OPEN ABDOMEN (OA) NEGATIVE PRESSURE THERAPY (NPT)
carousel.content: An ABThera™ OA NPT Dressing was placed intraoperatively into the open abdomen. The ABThera™ Visceral Protective Layer was tucked deep around the small pelvis, subdiaphragm and paracolic gutters to create a barrier between viscera and the abdominal wall.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA (Cont'd)
carousel.content: The ABThera™ Perforated Foam was measured and cut to fit inside the abdominal incision. The ABThera™ Drape and tubing set were placed over the dressing to create a seal. Pressure was initiated at −125mmHg to begin exudate removal and decrease edema, which were the primary goals of initiating therapy. The patient remained closely monitored in the intensive care unit.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA (Cont'd)
carousel.content: On open abdomen day 3, the ABThera™ OA NPT Dressing was removed and the wound appeared clean. Exudate was clear; no signs of fistula formation, and the fascia was closed primarily.

carousel.title: POST TREATMENT
carousel.content: The patient was extubated. V.A.C.® Therapy with a standard V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing was initiated over the fascia at −125mmHg with dressing changes every 48 hours until hospital discharge 8 days later.

carousel.title: DISCHARGE AND FOLLOW-UP
carousel.content: The patient was discharged on hospital day 15 with weekly follow-up. Stable cutaneous coverage was achieved by secondary intention at home. At his 3 month follow-up appointment, the patient was doing well and the wound was completely closed.

carousel.title: ABThera Case Study
carousel.content: Open Abdominal Wound Following Repair of Parastomal Hernia with Large Necrotic Colon

carousel.title: PATIENT
carousel.content: A 67-year-old obese female presented with colostomy from previous transverse colon resection, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, gastroesophageal reflux disease, sleep apnea, and a history of multiple hernia repairs.

carousel.title: DIAGNOSIS
carousel.content: The patient was admitted with abdominal pain and clinical signs of peritonitis. Leukocyte count was 17.3x103/mm3 and hemoglobin was 10.1g/dL. A laparoscopy performed upon admission revealed multiple adhesions, wire mesh from a prior incisional hernia repair, and a right parastomal hernia with small bowel incarceration (two-thirds).

carousel.title: INITIAL TREATMENT
carousel.content: Surgeons performed lysis of adhesions, resection of right colon, creation of end ileostomy, reduction of the right parastomal hernia, and excision of the previously placed wire mesh. The abdomen was left open for re-exploration and to prevent potential abdominal compartment syndrome.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA OPEN ABDOMEN (OA) NEGATIVE PRESSURE THERAPY (NPT)
carousel.content: An ABThera™ OA NPT Dressing was placed intraoperatively into the open abdomen. The ABThera™ Visceral Protective Layer was trimmed to fit the size of the defect and tucked inside the abdominal wall to completely cover the viscera and protect abdominal contents.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA (Cont'd)
carousel.content: The ABThera™ Perforated Foam was measured and cut to fit inside the abdominal incision.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA (Cont'd)
carousel.content: Additional foam was used to fill the parastomal hernia wound and create a bridge to the OA wound site. The ABThera™ Drape and tubing set were placed over the dressing to create a seal, and negative pressure was initiated at −125mmHg. Dressing changes and washouts were performed every 2-3 days for a total of 3 dressing changes.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA (Cont'd)
carousel.content: At the first dressing change on hospital day 4, an abdominal washout was performed along with debridement of the necrotic hernia sac. At the second dressing change on hospital day 8, the patient was taken to the operating room for a washout and removal of the ABThera™ OA NPT Dressing, and primary fascial closure was achieved.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA (Cont'd)
carousel.content: The patient was extubated and V.A.C.® Therapy with a standard V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing was initiated over the fascia to stimulate granulation tissue formation. Dressings were changed every 48 hours until discharge 11 days later.

carousel.title: DISCHARGE AND FOLLOW-UP
carousel.content: The patient was discharged on hospital day 19 with weekly follow-up. Stable cutaneous coverage was achieved by secondary intention at home. At 5 weeks post discharge, the patient was readmitted due to subacute bacterial endocarditis, acidosis, anemia and diabetes. Her abdominal wound remained closed. The patient was subsequently diagnosed with renal failure, but her abdomen remained closed at the 3-month follow-up.

carousel.title: ABThera Case Study
carousel.content: Open Abdominal Wound Following Intestinal Resection

carousel.title: PATIENT
carousel.content: A 68-year-old male presented with status epilepticus and respiratory and renal failure. The patient had a history of type 2 diabetes, seizures, dyslipidemia, hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, and chronic renal failure.

carousel.title: DIAGNOSIS
carousel.content: A laparoscopy performed upon admission revealed an intestinal obstruction.

carousel.title: INITIAL TREATMENT
carousel.content: After the laparoscopy, the patient was converted to an open abdomen following a culture and lavage. The surgeons found small intestine necrosis, which required a small bowel resection. The abdomen was left open for re-exploration.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA OPEN ABDOMEN (OA) NEGATIVE PRESSURE THERAPY (NPT)
carousel.content: An ABThera™ OA NPT Dressing was placed intraoperatively into the open abdomen. The ABThera™ Visceral Protective Layer was trimmed to fit the size of the defect and tucked inside the abdominal wall to completely cover the viscera.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA (Cont'd)
carousel.content: The ABThera™ Perforated Foam was measured and cut to fit inside the abdominal cavity.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA (Cont'd)
carousel.content: The ABThera™ Drape and tubing set were placed over the dressing to create a seal, and negative pressure was initiated at −125mmHg.

carousel.title: APPLICATION OF ABTHERA (Cont'd)
carousel.content: The open abdomen was closed by primary intention 48 hours later. During this time, there were no complications. V.A.C.® Therapy with a standard V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressing was initiated over the fascia to stimulate granulation tissue formation.

carousel.title: DISCHARGE AND FOLLOW-UP
carousel.content: The patient was discharged on hospital day 20 to a home care facility. At 3 weeks post discharge, the patient was readmitted due to seizures, but his abdominal wound remained clean and he remained on V.A.C.® Therapy. At his 5-week office visit, the patient’s wound was healing with good granulation tissue formation. At his 4-month follow-up visit, the wound was completely healed with no signs of hernia.

pages.title: ABThera Mechanism of Action
pages.content:
Describes the mechanism of action of the ABThera™ Open Abdomen Negative Pressure Therapy System.

Instructions for Use and Safety Information:
As with any prescription medical device, it is important to read and understand the detailed instructions for use and safety information (including contraindications, warnings, and precautions) applicable to your ABThera™ Negative Pressure Unit and dressing application that can be found with the therapy unit, and the dressing case. These sources provide detailed information concerning the proper application of all ABThera™ Dressings.

Failure to consult a physician and carefully read and follow all therapy unit and dressing instructions and safety information prior to each use may lead to improper product performance and the potential for serious or fatal injury. Do not adjust therapy unit settings or perform therapy application without directions from/or supervision by the clinical caregiver.

References:
1. Kaplan M, Banwell P, Orgill DP, Ivatury RR, Demetriades D, Moore FA, Miller P, Nicholas J, Henry S. Guidelines for the Management of the Open Abdomen. WOUNDS. 2005 Oct;17(Suppl 1):S1-S24.

2. Miller PR, Meredith JW, Johnson JC, Chang MC. Prospective evaluation of vacuum-assisted fascial closure after open abdomen: planned ventral hernia rate is substantially reduced. Annals of Surgery. 2004 May; 239(5): 608-614.

Studies conducted using V.A.C.® Therapy System with V.A.C.® GranuFoam™ Dressings.

pages.title: Prevena
pages.content:
Prevena™

Incision Management System

Specific indications, contraindication, warnings, precautions and safety information exist for the Prevena™ Incision Management System. Please consult a physician and product instructions for use prior to application.

Device Disposal: Follow local institutional protocols for infection control and waste disposal procedures. Local protocols should be based on the applicable federal, state and/or local government environmental regulations.

The first powered negative pressure product designed specifically for management of clean, closed surgical incisions. The Prevena™ Incision Management System covers and protects the incision from external infectious sources, negative pressure draws incision edges together, while removing fluid and infectious material.

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
Designed to create an environment that helps:

  • Hold incision edges together
  • Protect the incision site from external infectious sources
  • Remove fluids and infectious materials from the incision site

Small & simple

  • Battery-powered, single-patient use
  • Lightweight and portable
  • One-touch operation (pre-set negative pressure of 125mmHg)
  • 45mL canister

Self-adhesive, peel & place dressing

  • Integrated one-piece dressing (cutting or sizing not typically required)
  • Designed for use over the surgical incision and surrounding intact skin
  • Featuring 3M™ Tegaderm™* Dressing adhesive
  • Built-in pressure indicator
  • Designed to conform to patient contours

*3M™ and Tegaderm™ are trademarks of 3M™ Corporation.

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
The Prevena™ Incision Management System is intended to manage the environment of surgical incisions that continue to drain following sutured or stapled closure by maintaining a closed environment and removing exudate via the application of negative pressure wound therapy.

Contraindications

  • Sensitivity to silver

Warnings

  • Bleeding: Before applying the Prevena™ Incision Management System to patients who are at risk of bleeding complications due to the operative procedure or concomitant therapies and / or co-morbidities, ensure that hemostasis has been achieved and all tissue planes have been approximated. If active bleeding develops suddenly or in large amounts during therapy, or if frank blood is seen in the tubing or in the canister, the patient should leave the Prevena™ Incision Dressing in place, turn off Prevena™ 125 Therapy Unit and seek immediate emergency medical assistance.
  • Infected Wounds: As with any wound treatment, clinicians and patients / caregivers should frequently monitor the patient’s wound, periwound tissue and exudate for signs of infection, or other complications. Some signs of infection are fever, tenderness, redness, swelling, itching, rash, increased warmth in the wound or periwound area, prulent discharge, or strong odor. Infection can be serious, and can lead to complications such as pain, discomfort, fever, gangrene, toxic shock, septic shock and / or fatal injury. Some signs or complications of systemic infection are nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, fainting, sore throat with swelling of the mucus membranes, disorientation, high fever, refractory and / or orthostatic hypotension, or erythroderma (a sunburn-like rash). Silver in the interface layer of the Prevena™ Incision Dressing is not intended to treat infection, but to reduce bacterial colonization in the fabric. If infection develops, Prevena™ Therapy should be discontinued until the infection is treated.
  • Allergic Response: The Prevena™ Incision Dressing has an acrylic adhesive coating and a skin interface layer with silver, which may present a risk of an adverse reaction in patients who are allergic or hypersensitive to acrylic adhesives or silver. If a patient has a known allergy or hypersensitivity to these materials, do not use the Prevena™ Incision Management System. If any signs of allergic reaction, irritation or hypersensitivity develop, such as redness, swelling, rash, urticaria, or significant pruritus, patient should consult a physician immediately. If bronchospasm or more serious signs of allergic reaction appear, the patient should turn off the therapy unit and seek immediate emergency medical assistance.
  • Defibrillation: Remove the Prevena™ Incision Dressing if defibrillation is required in the area of dressing placement. Failure to remove the dressing may inhibit transmission of electrical energy and / or patient resuscitation.
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): The Prevena™ 125 Therapy Unit is MR Unsafe. Do not take the Prevena™ 125 Therapy Unit into the MR environment. The Prevena™ Incision Dressing can typically remain on the patient with minimal risk in an MR environment. Interruption of Prevena™ Therapy during MRI may reduce the effectiveness of Prevena™ Therapy. The Prevena™ Incision Dressing should pose no known hazards in an MR environment with the following conditions of use: static magnetic field of 3 Tesla or less, spatial gradient field of 720 Gauss/cm or less, and maximum whole-body-averaged specific absorption rate (SAR) of 3W/kg for 15 minutes of scanning.
  • Diagnostic Imaging: The Prevena™ Incision Dressing contains metallic silver that may impair visualization with certain imaging modalities.
  • Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy (HBO): Do not take the Prevena™ 125 Therapy Unit or Prevena™ Incision Dressing into a hyperbaric oxygen chamber; it is not designed for this environment, and should be considered a fire hazard. If Prevena™ Therapy is reinitiated after HBO treatment, do not readhere the same dressing, a new dressing must be applied.
  • Canister Full: If at any time while using the Prevena™ Incision Management System, the canister becomes full of fluid other than blood, indicated by a Maximum Capacity Alert or visual inspection, the patient should turn therapy unit off and contact the treating physician.

Precautions

  • Standard Precautions: To reduce the risk of transmission of bloodborne pathogens, apply standard precautions for infection control with all patients, per institutional protocol, regardless of their diagnosis or presumed infection status. In addition to gloves, use gown and goggles if exposure to body fluid is likely.
  • Circumferential Dressing Application: Avoid applying the Prevena™ Incision Dressing circumferentially. In cases where the clinician determines that the benefits of applying the Prevena™ Incision Dressing circumferentially outweighs the risk of circulatory compromise, extreme care should be taken not to stretch or pull the dressing when securing it. Attach the dressing loosely and stabilize edges with an elastic wrap if necessary. It is crucial to systematically and recurrently palpate distal pulses and assess distal circulatory status. If circulatory compromise is suspected, discontinue therapy and remove dressing.
  • Electrodes or Conductive Gel: Do not allow the Prevena™ Incision Dressing to come in contact with EKG or other electrodes or conductive gels during electronic monitoring or when taking electronic measurements.
  • Dressing Components: The Prevena™ Incision Dressing contains ionic silver (0.019%). Application of products containing silver may cause temporary tissue discoloration.
    • Always use Prevena™ dressings and canisters from sterile packages that have not been opened or damaged.
    • All components of the Prevena™ Incision Management System are for single use only. Do not re-use any component of this system.
    • To avoid trauma to the skin, do not pull or stretch the adhesive border of the dressing during application.

pages.title: Case Studies
pages.content: As with any case study, the results and outcomes should not be interpreted as a guarantee or warranty of similar results. Individual results may vary depending on the patient’s circumstances and condition.

carousel.title: Patient
carousel.content: A 70-year-old male patient presented with a non-ST elevation myocardial infarction.

carousel.title: Diagnosis
carousel.content: Medical history included type II diabetes, peripheral vascular disease (PVD), renal insufficiency, hyperlipidemia and pulmonary hypertension. After further investigation, patient was diagnosed with triple vessel coronary artery disease and severe mitral insufficiency. An urgent triple coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and mitral valve replacement (MVR) were performed.

carousel.title: Treatment
carousel.content: Due to the patient’s critical state, comorbidities, and combined procedures, he was at elevated risk for postoperative incision complications. The Prevena™ Incision Dressing was applied along the incision with special care taken to leave enough distance between the inferior aspect of the incision and the chest tubes to secure a proper seal. On postoperative Day 3, the patient cardiopulmonary arrested, requiring immediate resuscitative chest compressions. However, the integrity of the Prevena™ Incision Dressing was maintained.

carousel.title: Post Therapy
carousel.content: On postoperative Day 8, the Prevena™ Incision Dressing was removed.

carousel.title: Follow-up/Conclusion
carousel.content: The incision edges appeared well apposed and were healing appropriately. In contrast, the chest tube sites, which were not treated with Prevena™ Therapy, demonstrated some drainage. The patient was discharged home on postoperative Day 18 with his incision continuing to heal well.

carousel.title: Patient
carousel.content: A 71-year-old female patient required a right total hip arthroplasty.

carousel.title: Medical History
carousel.content: Medical history included morbid obesity (BMI of 40), hypertension, and osteoarthritis.

carousel.title: Treatment
carousel.content: Standard closure methods were used, which included multiple layers of subcutaneous sutures to close dead space and staples as final closure. The Prevena™ Incision Dressing was placed in the operating room.

carousel.title: Post Therapy
carousel.content: The Prevena™ Incision Dressing was removed on postoperative Day 5. The patient was then discharged to a rehabilitation center.

carousel.title: Patient
carousel.content: A 65-year-old male presented with progressive angina and positive exertional stress test.

carousel.title: Diagnosis
carousel.content: Medical history included diabetes mellitus, obesity (BMI of 38), and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The cardiac catheterization demonstrated severe, 3-vessel coronary artery disease and a CABG was performed.

carousel.title: Treatment
carousel.content: CABG x 4 was performed, utilizing left internal mammary artery to left anterior descending coronary artery and reverse saphenous vein grafts to the right coronary artery, ramus intermedius artery, and first diagonal artery separately. The standard median sternotomy incision was approximately 10 inches in length. Sternal reapproximation was performed with stainless steel cables and skin was closed with subcuticular sutures. The Prevena™ Incision Dressing was placed in the operating room.

carousel.title: Post Therapy
carousel.content: The dressing was removed on postoperative Day 5, and patient was discharged on postoperative Day 6.

pages.title: Graftjacket Xpress
pages.content:
Graftjacket® Xpress

Flowable Soft Tissue Scaffold

Every patient is different and individual patient results may vary. Before use, physicians must review all risk information and essential prescribing information which can be found in the Graftjacket® Xpress flowable soft tissue scaffold Instructions for Use.

Graftjacket® Xpress flowable soft tissue scaffold (FSTS) is micronized allograft human dermis, aseptically processed to remove cells and freeze-dried to remove moisture while preserving natural biologic components of the dermal matrix.

Regulatory Classification
Graftjacket® Xpress Scaffold is regulated by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as human tissue for transplantation. Graftjacket® Xpress Scaffold is processed and marketed in accordance with the FDA requirements for banked human tissue (21 CFR, Parts 1270 and 1271) and the Standards for Tissue Banking of the American Association of Tissue Banks (AATB). Graftjacket® Xpress Scaffold is compliant with the AATB Standards for Tissue Banking and the state guidelines of California, Florida, New York, Maryland, and Illinois.

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
Graftjacket® Xpress FSTS is a micronized form of Graftjacket® regenerative tissue matrix (processed acellular human dermis) that retains the natural biological components of human dermis necessary to aid the body in wound healing by supporting regeneration of host tissue. When reconstituted with sterile saline and applied to the wound following best practices for wound care, Graftjacket®:

  • Conforms to the shape of the wound and fills deep tunneling and irregularly contoured wounds.
  • May minimize the need for more extensive surgical intervention for ‘hard to heal’ patients.*
  • Replaces damaged or missing dermal tissue with ‘like’ tissue by supporting cellular repopulation and revascularization by host tissue.
  • Helps allow the patient to heal the wound, which may reduce the likelihood of amputation.

*Brigido, SA, et al. Use of an acellular flowable dermal replacement scaffold on lower extremity sinus tract wounds. Foot and Ankle Specialist. 2009 Apr;2(2):67-72.

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
Graftjacket® Xpress Scaffold supports the body’s repair of damaged or inadequate integumental tissue, such as deep dermal wounds or diabetic ulcers.

Each package of Graftjacket® Xpress Scaffold is intended for use in one patient, on a single occasion.

Contraindications
Graftjacket® Xpress Scaffold is contraindicated for use in any patient who is sensitive to polysorbate 20 or to any of the antibiotics listed on the package.

Because of the particle size, Graftjacket® Xpress Scaffold should not be used in the periocular, forehead or glabellar areas.

Warning
Processing of the tissue, laboratory testing, and careful donor screening minimize the risks of the donor tissue transmitting disease to the recipient patient. As with any processed donor tissue, the Graftjacket® Xpress Scaffold cannot be guaranteed to be free of all pathogens. No long-term studies have been conducted to evaluate the carcinogenic or mutagenic potential or reproductive impact of the clinical application of Graftjacket® Xpress Flowable Soft Tissue Scaffold.

pages.title: Scheduled Below the Knee Amputation Avoided
pages.content: Scheduled Below the Knee Amputation Avoided

carousel.title: Graftjacket Xpress Case Study
carousel.content: Scheduled Below the Knee Amputation Avoided

carousel.title: Situation
carousel.content:
Preoperative
74 year-old, insulin dependent diabetic female had two ulcers on the plantar and lateral aspects of her left foot.

carousel.title: Situation (cont’d)
carousel.content:
Debrided ulcer tunneled to bone
Physician recommended below the knee amputation. Patient requested other treatment options be explored.

carousel.title: Treatment
carousel.content:
Graftjacket® Xpress FSTS was used to fill the wound completely
With the patient’s consent, Graftjacket® regenerative tissue matrix was selected to treat both ulcers. Plantar ulcer was debrided and grafted with Graftjacket® regenerative tissue matrix. Lateral ulcer was debrided, but found to have tunneled down to bone; additional clinical intervention was required. Graftjacket® Xpress flowable soft tissue scaffold (FSTS) was applied to completely fill the wound.

carousel.title: Outcome
carousel.content:
Five days postoperative
6 days post treatment, the original wound size had reduced by 50%.

carousel.title: Outcome (cont'd)
carousel.content:
13 days postoperative; wound is at skin level
Within 2 weeks, the wound was considered superficial.

carousel.title: Outcome (cont'd)
carousel.content:
Eight weeks postoperative
After 8 weeks, the wound had completely healed. Amputation was no longer deemed necessary.

carousel.title: Additional Information
carousel.content:
Case images courtesy of Steven Brigido, DPM and David Armstrong, DPM; used by permission.

For tunneling wounds, Graftjacket® Xpress FSTS should be utilized in conjunction with best practices in wound care, including adequate debridement and infection management when appropriate.

As with any case study, the results and outcomes should not be interpreted as a guarantee or warranty of similar results. Individual results may vary depending on the patient’s circumstances and condition.

pages.title: Graftjacket RTM
pages.content:
Graftjacket®

Regenerative Tissue Matrix

Every patient is different and patient results may vary. Before use, physicians must review all risk information and essential prescribing information which can be found in the Graftjacket® Regenerative Tissue Matrix Instructions for Use.

Graftjacket® regenerative tissue matrix (RTM) is a thin, fenestrated acellular dermal matrix designed for single application that supports regeneration of host tissue.

Graftjacket® RTM is donated allograft human dermis, aseptically processed to remove cells and freeze-dried to remove moisture while preserving biologic components and structure of the dermal matrix.

Regulatory Classification
Graftjacket® regenerative tissue matrix is regulated by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) as human tissue for transplantation. Graftjacket® matrix is processed and marketed in accordance with the FDA’s requirements for banked human tissue (21 CFR, Part 1270 and Part 1271) and Standards for Tissue Banking of the American Association of Tissue Banks (AATB). Graftjacket® matrix is compliant with the AATB Standards for Tissue Banking and the state guidelines of California, Florida, New York, Maryland, and Illinois.

pages.title: Features and Benefits
pages.content:
Our proprietary process leaves an intact, acellular matrix that allows the body to initiate its own tissue regeneration process.

Donor Screening

Complies with FDA and AATB standards for donated human tissue.

Proprietary tissue processing

  • Non-damaging steps designed to maintain an intact matrix and preserve biologic components
  • Non-damaging freeze-drying process
  • Product release testing

Graftjacket® RTM

  • Helps reduce the body's rejection response
  • Designed to support cellular repopulation and revascularization by host tissue
  • Helps reduce inflammatory response*,1

Graftjacket® RTM is an intact, human acellular dermal matrix for diabetic foot ulcers, including superficial and deep wounds:

  • In a 12-week prospective, randomized, controlled study, beginning at the 3-week follow-up evaluation, the proportion of healed ulcers in the study group (received Graftjacket® RTM) was at least 15% higher than the control group (received Moist Wound Therapy) (p = 0.0289, Odds Ratio = 2.7).**, 2
  • Requires only one application, in most cases, and can be placed in the operating room or outpatient setting.
  • V.A.C.® Therapy can be used to prepare the wound bed for grafting and as a bolster following Graftjacket® RTM application.
  • Replaces damaged or missing tissue with ‘like’ tissue by supporting cellular repopulation and revascularization by host tissue.
  • Provided in a thin sheet for conformability to the wound, maintaining surface area contact when sutured or stapled in place.
  • Fenestrated to allow for wound fluid to escape.

*Data based on non-human primate studies; correlation of these results in humans have not yet been established.

** A 12-week prospective, randomized, controlled, multicenter study using Graftjacket® RTM in the treatment of UT Grade 1 & 2 diabetic foot ulcers, N = 46 received Graftjacket® RTM (4x4cm). N = 39 received standard of care wound management (Moist Wound Therapy with alginates, foams, hydrocolloids or hydrogels).

1. Sandor M, et al. Host response to implanted porcine-derived biologic materials in a primate model of abdominal wall repair. Tissue Eng Part A. 2008; 14(12): 2021-2031.

2. Reyzelman A, Crews RT, Moore JC, et al. Clinical effectiveness of an acellular dermal regenerative tissue matrix compared to standard wound management in healing diabetic foot ulcers: a prospective, randomised, multicentre study. Int Wound J. 2009; 6(3):196-208.

pages.title: Indications / Safety
pages.content:
Graftjacket® regenerative tissue matrix – Ulcer Repair provides a scaffold for the body's repair or replacement of damaged or inadequate integumental tissue, such as diabetic ulcers, or for other homologous uses of human integument.

Each package of Graftjacket® matrix is intended for use in one patient, on a single occasion.

Contraindications
Graftjacket® matrix is contraindicated for use in any patient who is sensitive to polysorbate 20 or to any of the antibiotics listed on the package.

Warning
Processing of the tissue, laboratory testing, and careful donor screening minimize the risks of the donor tissue transmitting disease to the recipient patient. As with any processed donor tissue, Graftjacket® matrix cannot be guaranteed to be free of all pathogens. No long-term studies have been conducted to evaluate the carcinogenic or mutagenic potential reproductive impact of the clinical application of Graftjacket® Regenerative Tissue Matrix.

pages.title: Wound Bed Preparation Using V.A.C. Therapy

carousel.title: Situation
carousel.content:
47 year-old male with Type 2 diabetes, HIV and peripheral neuropathy presented with an infected diabetic foot ulcer under the right fifth metatarsal head.

This case study was provided by Lee C. Rogers, DPM.

carousel.title: Treatment
carousel.content: The ulcer was debrided in the OR and the patient was admitted to the hospital on IV antibiotics. Osteomyelitis was ruled out by bone biopsy and x-ray. After the infection was controlled, V.A.C.® Therapy was initiated. After 12 days, it was determined that V.A.C.® Therapy met its goal; the wound bed was granular and therefore ready for Graftjacket® RTM application.

carousel.title: Treatment
carousel.content: Graftjacket® RTM was sutured into the wound and covered with a non-adherent dressing. Offloading was prescribed.

carousel.title: Outcome
carousel.content: Graftjacket® RTM absorbed in the center of the wound.

carousel.title: Outcome
carousel.content: The wound epithelialized with healthy plantar skin within 6 weeks.

carousel.title: Situation
carousel.content:
Patient with incomplete transmetatarsal amputation
presents with new ulcer

60 year-old male with Type 2 diabetes and previous foot surgery, including an incomplete transmetatarsal amputation on the right foot, presents with a new ulcer under the first metatarsal head. Infection, including osteomyelitis, was ruled out. The wound was debrided to healthy bleeding tissue.

Case images courtesy of Lee C. Rogers, DPM; used by permission.

carousel.title: Treatment
carousel.content: Graftjacket® RTM was applied in the clinic and sutured in place.

carousel.title: Treatment
carousel.content: Graftjacket® RTM incorporated over 4 weeks and the superficial layer dessicated and sloughed at that time.

carousel.title: Outcome
carousel.content: The wound was 90% closed and best practices for wound care were followed until complete closure 2 weeks later.

carousel.title: Outcome
carousel.content: After 6 months, the healed wound had remodeled and healthy plantar skin was noted at this location.

pages.title: Online - KCI Express
pages.content:
KCI Express® is a convenient, web-based system that allows you to manage orders for KCI V.A.C.® Therapy rentals and supplies. KCI Express® works across multiple care settings, allowing you to use an integrated system to manage your patients’ wound treatment needs for both inpatient and transition settings. KCI Express® simplifies the entire ordering process including initial order submission, delivery, tracking, analysis, and service via an intuitive Web-based browser interface. If your facility is already enrolled in KCI Express®, contact your facility's KCI Express® administrator for a user account.

For additional enrollment assistance, contact your KCI Sales Representative or the KCI Express® Support team at 1-800-275-4524 ext. 65080 (Monday – Friday, 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. Central Time). For general information about KCI Express®, tap below, or visit http://www.kci1.com/KCI1/kciexpress.

For more information tap below.

pages.title: About KCI
pages.content:
A Spirit of Innovation

Kinetic Concepts, Inc. is a leading global medical technology company devoted to the discovery, development, manufacture and marketing of innovative, high-technology therapies and products for the wound care market.

Headquartered in San Antonio, Texas, for more than three decades KCI has significantly advanced the science of wound healing. The success of KCI can be traced to a history deeply rooted in innovation and a passion for significantly improving patient outcomes while reducing the overall cost of care for patients around the world.

Proven Clinical Outcomes

Since its introduction in 1996, V.A.C® Therapy has revolutionized the way caregivers treat a wide variety of wounds.

With more published clinical evidence than any other form of Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT), V.A.C.® Therapy has been shown to provide positive clinical and economic outcomes. V.A.C.® Therapy has been selected as the treatment of choice for more than 7 million wounds worldwide*.

*As of July 2012

For more information about KCI, please visit

pages.title: About this App
pages.content:
The KCI Wound Care app is a free resource for US healthcare professionals to learn about KCI wound care products.

KCI has a wide portfolio of industry-leading wound care products that includes negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT), products for the management of the open abdomen, and of clean, closed surgical incisions, as well as regenerative tissue matrices.

Worldwide, over 7 million wounds have been treated with KCI V.A.C.® Therapy Systems. At KCI, we are committed to helping patients heal. For over 35 years, we have led the way in the development of new technologies and therapies designed to make wound healing more manageable for caregivers and more comfortable for patients.

The KCI Wound Care app includes:

  • Product Resources: intended use statements, application videos, product labeling and ordering information.
  • News: Find the latest KCI news about its products, press releases and app updates.
  • Convention Info: medical tradeshows where KCI will be exhibiting.
  • Contact Info: For more information or how to order KCI wound care products.

The information included in this app has been prepared for and is intended for viewing exclusively within the United States of America by healthcare professionals. Patients should consult with their healthcare providers regarding their specific medical conditions, the information provided on this app and the potential risks and benefits of treatments.

This app contains information about products which are for sale or rental in the U.S. only.

pages.title: Closed Incision Management
pages.content:
Incisions can carry complication risks. Therefore, there is a sense of urgency associated with the early management of incisions.

Please refer to the Prevena™ Instructions for Use for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Dehisced Wounds
pages.content:
A dehisced wound is a premature bursting open or splitting of a surgical wound along natural or surgical suture lines.

Please refer to the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations. For V.A.C.Ulta™, refer to the V.A.C.Ulta™ User Manual.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Flaps
pages.content:
A flap is a type of full-thickness skin graft, which includes the entire thickness of the skin.

Please refer to the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations. For V.A.C.Ulta™, refer to the V.A.C.Ulta™ User Manual.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Infected Wounds
pages.content:
Wounds caused by physical interruption of the skin with subsequent organism entry and replication which leads to infection.

Please refer to the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations. For V.A.C.Ulta™, refer to the V.A.C.Ulta™ User Manual.

Featured products should be used in conjunction with appropriate infection treatments.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Abdominal Wounds with Exposed Viscera
pages.content:
A technique, also known as laparostomy, in which the fascia is left open intentionally to avoid elevation of intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) and where surgical re-exploration is desirable. Temporary abdominal closure (TAC) is achieved using a dressing or technology intended to protect the exposed viscera.

Please refer to the ABThera™ Instructions for Use for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Abdominal Wounds with Intact Fascia
pages.content:
Wounds with separation of wound edges or loss of wound edge approximation may occur for many reasons, systemic issues, mechanical stress or surgical technique. Open incisions can carry increased risk of further complications.

Please refer to the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations. For V.A.C.Ulta™, refer to the V.A.C.Ulta™ User Manual.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Open Surgical Wounds
pages.content:
A post surgical wound that is open with the skin edges not closely approximated. Healing will not occur by incisional healing but by secondary (heals by scar tissue replacing the tissue defect) or tertiary (delayed primary) intention (wound is left open initially; after a short period of time, wound edges are approximated and the wound is closed).

Please refer to the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations. For V.A.C.Ulta™, refer to the V.A.C.Ulta™ User Manual.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Partial Thickness Burns
pages.content:
Partial thickness burns are also known as first and second degree burns.

Please refer to the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations. For V.A.C.Ulta™, refer to the V.A.C.Ulta™ User Manual.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Skin Grafts
pages.content:
A skin graft is a patch of skin that is surgically removed from one area of the body and transplanted to another area.

Please refer to the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations. For V.A.C.Ulta™, refer to the V.A.C.Ulta™ User Manual.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Traumatic Wounds
pages.content:
A traumatic wound is a wound that occurs in response to hard and/or soft tissue trauma, including injuries to bone, muscle, ligament and tendons, as well as spinal cord injuries.

Please refer to the V.A.C.® Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations. For V.A.C.Ulta™, refer to the V.A.C.Ulta™ User Manual.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Diabetic Ulcers
pages.content:
A diabetic foot ulcer is an open sore or wound that most commonly occurs on the bottom of the foot in approximately 15 percent of patients with diabetes.

Please refer to the V.A.C. Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Pressure Ulcers
pages.content:
A pressure ulcer, or bed sore, is a localized injury to the skin and/or underlying tissue usually over a bony prominence, as a result of pressure, or pressure in combination with shear and/or friction. KCI designs and manufactures a number of products for pressure ulcer prevention and treatment.

Please refer to the V.A.C. Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.

pages.title: Venous Leg Ulcers
pages.content:
Venous ulcers are most commonly found in the area above the ankle but can include any area below the knee. The leg may become swollen, causing the skin surrounding the ulcer to become dry, itchy, and sometimes brownish in color.

Please refer to the V.A.C. Therapy Clinical Guidelines for wound specific information, including therapy goals and clinical considerations.

Tap the Featured Products button below to see the KCI products designed to help manage this condition.
